PostValue.explanation: With only the title available, this appears to be a review of a niche organisation focused on insect protection. For the EA/rationalist community it could be somewhat useful (informing cause prioritisation within animal welfare and insect-sentience debates), but is unlikely to be load-bearing unless it presents novel, large-scale evidence or interventions about insect sentience or cost‑effective impact. For general humanity the likely practical impact is small unless the post contained surprising global-scale findings. Overall importance is low–moderate, contingent on the post containing unusually strong or novel claims.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) The post currently lacks a clear, reproducible evaluation methodology and concrete findings — readers don’t know what you judged, how you judged it, or what evidence supports your conclusions. Actionable fix: add an explicit scope and objective, list the evaluation criteria you used (e.g. impact, tractability, neglectedness, cost-effectiveness), describe your data sources and methods (literature review, interviews, metrics used), and include an executive summary with your main conclusion and confidence level.

2) There is no empirical evidence, citations, or cost/scale estimates to back up claims. Actionable fix: cite primary sources (papers, reports, SFI materials, interviews), quantify scale and costs where possible (even order-of-magnitude), and include simple cost-effectiveness or counterfactual comparisons (e.g. expected welfare/ecosystem benefit per dollar or per hour). If precise numbers aren’t available, present transparent assumptions and sensitivity ranges.

3) Major counterarguments and trade-offs are not addressed (unintended ecological effects, species prioritization, measurability of insect welfare, regulatory/practical feasibility, and conflicts of interest). Actionable fix: add a dedicated section that (a) lists the strongest plausible objections, (b) explains how your evaluation handles them or why they don’t overturn your conclusion, and (c) discloses any potential COIs or biases. This will make the review more credible and useful to an EA audience.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: The feedback identifies major, credibility-destroying omissions (no reproducible method, no citations/estimates, no engagement with key counterarguments or COIs). The suggested fixes are concrete and would materially improve the review’s usefulness to an EA audience. These changes may lengthen the post but are essential; they don’t necessarily prove the author’s thesis false, so a top score isn’t warranted.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I don't have any record of a notable EA/rationalist figure named 'VettedCauses' in my training data — no major publications, talks, or widely-cited posts tied to that handle. It reads like a pseudonymous/online account with little or no public visibility; if you can share a link or more context I can reassess.

PostClarity.explanation: The post has only a title and no body content. Strength: the title indicates the general topic (Society for the Protection of Insects). Weaknesses: there is no text, no thesis, no arguments or structure, and no evidence — making it impossible to understand the author's point or evaluate claims. Suggest adding a clear summary, a stated purpose, supporting points, and a brief conclusion.

PostNovelty.explanation: The post content is empty and the title alone ('Society for the Protection of Insects Review') suggests a review of an organization rather than presenting new theoretical claims. The idea of protecting or advocating for insect welfare/conservation is already well-known to the general public and regularly discussed within EA/longtermist circles (and among conservationists), so there is little or no novel content to evaluate.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: I cannot evaluate the post because no content was provided. With no arguments or data to assess, reasoning and evidence cannot be judged; assign minimal scores by default. Please supply the post text or a link and I will re-evaluate with detailed comments.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: VettedCauses’ core empirical claims are well-supported by publicly available sources: SPI’s own website and LinkedIn confirm it was founded in 2023 and that it publicly lists three initiatives (pesticide reform, endangered insects, insect factory farming). VettedCauses’ statements that SPI has little public evidence of concrete interventions, that the pesticide “Learn More” page did not load (or is unavailable), and that SPI reports $0 spending in its first fiscal year are supported by SPI’s website and SPI’s public replies on the EA Forum. VettedCauses’ stronger claim that SPI “never litigated a case / never filed a lawsuit” is supported by the absence of any public filings, press releases, or court records surfaced by web search and by SPI’s own description (they describe preparation for litigation but do not point to filed cases). Limitations: an exhaustive PACER/state-court search was not run here (absence of evidence on the open web is not absolute proof of no filings), some VettedCauses assertions rely on private communications (not publicly verifiable), and a normative claim in the review (“impossible to reform pesticide use with $0”) is opinion rather than pure empirical fact.
sources: VettedCauses review: "SPI: The Litigators That Have Never Litigated a Case" (VettedCauses, review published June 25, 2025).
VettedCauses review: "Society for the Protection of Insects Review" (VettedCauses, references checked June 19–26, 2025).

Society for the Protection of Insects — official website (protectinsects.org) — homepage and Initiatives / Protect Endangered Species page (shows stated initiatives and content; pesticide page link was unreachable in automated check).
Society for the Protection of Insects — LinkedIn company profile (shows 'Founded 2023' and organization details).

Society for the Protection of Insects — EA Forum account / public response thread (SPI’s reply stating they 'spent $0 in our entire first fiscal year (2024-2025)' and describing confidential preparation for litigation).

Fisher II et al., 'Breaking the cycle: Reforming pesticide regulation to protect pollinators' (Bioscience, 2023) — used as background evidence that pesticide reform is a real scientific/policy issue (supports why claims about pesticide reform are non-trivial).
